steps.title: Choose 22 gauge wire in the color of your choice.
steps.content: Choose 22 gauge wire in the color of your choice. You can select any type of jewelry wire you like to make ear cuffs. Jewelry wire is available at craft supply stores in a variety of sizes and colors. The wire will needs to be thick enough to a hold its shape after you bend it and flexible enough to tighten and loosen it when you take the cuff off and on. A 22-guage wire works well. You can find wire that is finished with different colors, such as copper, red, blue, green, etc., or you can go with a plain silver colored wire. [1] X Research source You will only need a few inches of wire to create an ear cuff, but wire is usually sold in spool that is a few feet long.

steps.title: Measure the part of your ear where you want to wear the cuff.
steps.content: Measure the part of your ear where you want to wear the cuff. Take a 2 in (5.1 cm) piece of string in both hands and hold it up to your ear. Wrap it around the part of your ear where you want to put your cuff. Use your fingers to pinch off the string at the locations where you want the cuff to begin and end. Then, hold the string next to a ruler to figure out how long your wire will need to be. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Cut about 20 centimetres (7.9 in) of wire.
steps.content: Cut about 20 centimetres (7.9 in) of wire. Cut your first length of wire using a pair of sharp scissors or wire cutters. Cut straight across the wire to avoid creating a pointed edge. [3] X Research source When in doubt, give yourself a little longer piece of wire to work with—you can always cut it later.

steps.title: Smooth out the edges of the wire.
steps.content: Smooth out the edges of the wire. Use a metal file to smooth the ends of the wire. Move the file back and forth across 1 end of the wire until it feels smooth when you run your finger across it, and then repeat on the other end of the wire. This will help to prevent jagged edges from scratching your ear when you wear the ear cuff. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Grip the end of the wire with the pliers and create a small circular hook.
steps.content: Grip the end of the wire with the pliers and create a small circular hook. You should use needle-nose pliers (they taper into a point) for the greatest control. Bend the end into a small round hook, almost like a pin head. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Measure your cuff length from the bottom of the circle.
steps.content: Measure your cuff length from the bottom of the circle. Take your ruler and measure down from the little bent circle of wire. If your measurement for the cuff was 1 inch (2.5 cm), then move 1 inch (2.5 cm) down the wire. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Bend the wire back on itself at your measurement.
steps.content: Bend the wire back on itself at your measurement. Turn the wire back so that it is doubled up on itself (kind of like a paper clip). You'll have a U-shaped bend with the wire extending up on one side and the hook on the other. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Shape the wire into a zig-zag.
steps.content: Shape the wire into a zig-zag. Bend the wire back so that it is even with your hook. Then, take the long piece of wire and bend the whole thing into a "Z" shape. Keep bending the wire back and forth like this until you've made a complete zig-zag shape. You should have 1 free piece of wire hanging off the last curve. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Use your pliers to create another hook right at the last bend of the wire.
steps.content: Use your pliers to create another hook right at the last bend of the wire. Right now, you have a long zig-zagging piece of wire, with a hook on 1 end and a free end of wire on the other. With the pliers, grab the wire right at the last bend before the free end of wire, then use your fingers to rotate the wire around the pliers and create another hook. [9] X Research source

steps.title: Cut off the excess wire so you have hooks on both ends of the wire.
steps.content: Cut off the excess wire so you have hooks on both ends of the wire. You'll have a little "W" when you are done, with hooks on the top of the letter. Cut the excess wire, and use your hands to mold both ends into little hooks. [10] X Research source

steps.title: Mold your ear cuff around a large pen or Sharpie.
steps.content: Mold your ear cuff around a large pen or Sharpie. To get the right curve for an ear cuff, take the whole shape you have created and bend it around a pen, or another cylindrical object. A normal permanent marker is usually perfect, but smaller pens may be too thin to effectively round off the cuff. [11] X Research source Once you put the cuff on your ear, you can use your fingers to lightly mold it into place even more, so it will stick to your ear.

steps.title: Measure, cut, and bend a hook into the end of your wire like normal.
steps.content: Measure, cut, and bend a hook into the end of your wire like normal. Use the string to measure out the width of your cuff. Then, cut about 20 centimeter (8 in) of wire off for your cuff and make the small loop with the point of the pliers around the very end of wire. [12] X Research source

steps.title: Bend the wire back on itself to make a figure 8.
steps.content: Bend the wire back on itself to make a figure 8. Place half of the pliers in the loop, and the other underneath. Then, bend the wire around the pliers to form a figure 8 at the bottom of the wire. [13] X Research source

steps.title: Create 1 more loop to make a clover.
steps.content: Create 1 more loop to make a clover. Bend the wire above the figure 8, then curve it back down so you have a little 3-leaf clover, with the wire pointing downward. [14] X Research source

steps.title: Create a zigzag pattern with the remaining wire.
steps.content: Create a zigzag pattern with the remaining wire. Keep doubling the wire up until you have roughly 1 free length of wire left. You should be making a sideways M or W shaped center for your cuff. [15] X Research source

steps.title: Repeat the process to create a clover on the other end of the wire.
steps.content: Repeat the process to create a clover on the other end of the wire. If desired, you can finish the other end of the wire with a clover, or you can just make a loop on the other end. [16] X Research source

steps.title: Bend the cuff around your pen for a perfectly shaped ear cuff.
steps.content: Bend the cuff around your pen for a perfectly shaped ear cuff. Remember that you may want to experiment with the pen size, and need to mold the final shape a bit by hand. [17] X Research source

steps.title: Bend the wire about 2 centimeter (0.8 in) from the end into a loop.
steps.content: Bend the wire about 2 centimeter (0.8 in) from the end into a loop. Keep the extra length of wire on both sides. Use the pliers to bend a loop into the wire, turning it into a subtle L-shape. The "ends" extending off the loop should be perpendicular to the wire. [18] X Research source

steps.title: Measure out your cuff width from the bottom of the loop down the wire.
steps.content: Measure out your cuff width from the bottom of the loop down the wire. Measure down the long end, away from your loop, then pinch this spot with the pliers. [19] X Research source

steps.title: Bend the wire back on itself at your measurement point.
steps.content: Bend the wire back on itself at your measurement point. Tuck it back behind the loop, keeping it back behind the cuff. [20] X Research source

steps.title: Measure out your cuff width and bend it back behind the loop 1 last time.
steps.content: Measure out your cuff width and bend it back behind the loop 1 last time. Things will look a bit like a bow at this point, or a tied up paperclip. There is the loop in front, with a small wire hanging down, and long rounded wire behind the loop. There should still be a long area of wire still available behind the loop. [21] X Research source

steps.title: Bend the wire back down over the front to form a second loop.
steps.content: Bend the wire back down over the front to form a second loop. Now the bow shape will start to come together. There should be 2 loops on top and the hanging bits of wire below, with a long, oval-like wire behind everything. [22] X Research source

steps.title: Wrap some of the remaining wire around the center of the bow.
steps.content: Wrap some of the remaining wire around the center of the bow. Come up and around the center of your 2 bows to hold everything in place. Use your fingers and the pliers to keep adjusting, keeping things in place and shaping the bow how you want it. Cut off any excess wire and sand any jagged edges. [23] X Research source

steps.title: Bend only the long oval of wire to create the cuff.
steps.content: Bend only the long oval of wire to create the cuff. Use the pen to shape the center part of the cuff, but do not bend the bow. This is your cuff, and the bow needs to stay nice and flat. Simply bend this long cuff around your pen, molding it so it fits on your ear. [24] X Research source

steps.title: Measure, cut, and sand off 2–3 centimeter (0.79–1.2 in) of wire.
steps.content: Measure, cut, and sand off 2–3 centimeter (0.79–1.2 in) of wire. This small little cuff is meant to fit on your "tragus," the little, rounded flap where your ear meets your jawbone. If you have larger ears, go closer to 3 centimetres (1.2 in). [25] X Research source

steps.title: Bend the wire in half so the 2 sides are as close as possible.
steps.content: Bend the wire in half so the 2 sides are as close as possible. Use the pliers and your fingers to bring both sides of the wire close, so that they are basically doubled up. [26] X Research source

steps.title: Make 2 little spiral hooks on the both ends of the wire.
steps.content: Make 2 little spiral hooks on the both ends of the wire. These should be pointing towards each other. You'll end up with a heart-shaped set of wires. Use the pliers to try and keep the bottom nice and tight. [27] X Research source

steps.title: Use the pliers to keep molding your heart shape.
steps.content: Use the pliers to keep molding your heart shape. Pinch the wire with the ends of the pliers and turn the pliers in the direction you want the heart to curve. The tips of the pliers are really good to bend small circles or loops around. [28] X Research source

steps.title: Bend the entire shape over a small pen.
steps.content: Bend the entire shape over a small pen. This is the curve that keeps it on your tragus. Use your fingers and/or the pliers to mold the wire so that it fits snugly on your ear. [29] X Research source
